ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This was the best course I've taken so far at Yale. Rick is an incredible professor and I wish he taught more. All of the readings selected were fantastic, and the structure of the syllabus clearly demonstrated an amount of care and thoughtfulness not often seen with other faculty. Rick brought in alumni to work with us on an interesting and innovative final project. Even his exams were interesting and strangely fun to complete. This course is a must for any student interested in coastal issues.

This course has such great potential. It is the only course on this topic at FES, and the professor has a wealth of insider experience and knowledge about the field. He is eager to facilitate learning and is very invested in his students' success. The main thing I would change is the format. Student presentations on course material were not helpful to prepare or listen through. For many of the lectures, it was essentially a student teaching the class with some guidance from the professor -- I would have much preferred a lecture from Rick himself. Similarly, in a three hour lecture I would also hope to have more guest lecturers. That is, the first hour could be a lecture by the professor, the second hour could be a guest lecturer visit, and the first hour could be devoted to discussion. Or, the first 40 minutes could be lecture from the professor, the next 20 minutes could be a student presentation to present the guest lecturer, then an hour of guest lecturing, and then an hour of discussion. Or something like that! Also, perhaps Rick could collect student questions/comments about the reading material and use those to guide discussion. Basically, I think the format could be more dynamic, more engaging, and less reliant on student lectures. The final assignment, a testimony to Congress, was useful. The midterm was somewhat useful, though I think a policy memo (or two) would have perhaps been better suited for the content of the course.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This class was amazing. The readings were all fascinating and incredibly well organized, complimenting each other perfectly. I came away from the course having a very thorough understanding of the policy process and coastal issues.
The readings Rick chooses are terrific. There are a lot but it's worth getting through all of them - you will learn so much.

Rick's explanations positively brought the field of coastal policy to life for me. I had very little exposure to this field prior to taking this course, and it provided me with an understanding and enthusiasm of the policy process which exceeded my expectations. All of the readings were well selected, interesting, and relevant. 10/10.

Enjoyed the opportunity to meet the two guests. Also enjoyed the opportunity to write the testimony to congress. The professor's lectures and his book were very interesting, and the flow of the content/syllabus was solid. I also appreciated the extent to which current events/political conversation were brought into the course.
The hearings

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The task of becoming an "expert" on a subject seems quite daunting at first. While it enabled me to learn a lot about the subject, I would have found it helpful to receive more explanation and/or facilitation on the matter.
See above re. course format. Also, far too many readings assigned. It was impossible to do them all to the extent they deserved.
The professors know a lot about the topic. I think that the class should not be student led.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It was fantastic. Rick, as well as my fellow students, touched on the readings in a highly relevant way, and extracted teachable content.
NA

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This was unquestionably the most important and valuable course provided at F&ES for someone who is focusing on marine issues and fisheries policy.

I am interested in marine policy and this class was a perfect fit for my interests. It was very interesting to both build knowledge in science and legal issues surrounding the coast, but also develop an understanding of theories behind why we govern these spaces the way we do.
While policy is not at the core of my curriculum, it broadened my horizons and made me more comfortable in my field.
This course speaks directly to my interest in coastal management. The governance piece was new to me.
The course feels to fluffy sometimes and is difficult to know we're to fit it

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above. This course provided one of the only opportunities at F&ES to study fisheries and marine policy.
To broaden my horizons and get exposure to the policy process, especially considering the impact of the Trump presidency on my field.
Very interested in coastal management, and was interested in learning more about the governance component.
Because of the topic. However it's not applied neither theoretical. I don't know where to fit it

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!

This class went above and beyond my expectations. I feel well prepared for my summer internship in marine policy and this course was a perfect complement for my environmental protection clinic project as well.
They far exceeded my expectations.

Not quite. I think a format adjustment would make a really big difference though. Like I said, i think this course has really great potential, and it needs to be offered because it is one of the few classes at FES that covers this material. Just needs to be revamped a bit.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: NA

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Absolutely take this course. Rick is wonderful and the readings and lectures are designed brilliantly.
Take it! Do all of the readings, seriously.
I would strongly advise any student at FES to take this course. Rick is an incredible teacher and mentor.
Take this course if the format changes. If you are interested in coastal issues (wetlands, drilling, sea level rise, etc.) this is a good overview of the intersectionality of those areas.
It's very in the air and really to the rrasings lo
